event.name: Northwest Colonial Festival 2018
event.about: An annual colonial festival (August 9-12, 2018) with a colonial village and daily reenactments of the Battles of Lexington and Concord at the George Washington Inn and Washington Lavender Farm, located between Sequim and Port Angeles, Washington.
event.location: George Washington Inn,939 Finn Hall Road, Port Angeles, Washington, 98362
event.donateText: Tax-deductible donations to the George Washington Society, a fully recognized 501 (c)(3)educationalnon-profit organization, are appreciated.

speakers.name: John Redmayne
speakers.about: John Redmayne is commander of the the 7th Company Brigade of Guards, His majesty's forces at the festival.

speakers.name: Lady Redmayne
speakers.about: Born in Liverpool, England in 1744, Elizabeth Redmayne , yada yada yada

speakers.name: Robert Kingsley
speakers.oneLiner: A man with a knack for cutting your spitting image

speakers.name: Lt. Col. Josiah Harmar
speakers.about: Lieutenant Colonel Josiah Harmar was commissioned as a captain in the 6th Pennsylvania Regiment of the Continental Army in 1775. He fought in the Battle of Quebec and served directly under George Washington at Valley Forge. The Commander in Chief held Harmar in high regard stating that he was, "personally known to me as one of the best officers in the Army." Congress chose him to deliver the ratified Treaty of Paris, which officially ended the War for American Independence, to Benjamin Franklin in France, where the the Marquis de Lafayette introduced him to King Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette. Under the US Constitution, Harmar would serve as the Army's most senior officer for six and a half years.

speakers.name: Martha Washington
speakers.about: Born on June 2, 1731, in New Kent County, Virginia, Martha Washington married a wealthy plantation owner before becoming a widow and inheriting his estate. She wed Colonel George Washington in 1759 and became U.S. first lady upon his eventual ascendancy to the presidency. Martha was known for her aplomb and large social events, though she actually preferred privacy.

speakers.name: Samuel Quincy
speakers.about: Samuel Quincy was the solicitor general (attorney general) of the colony of Massachusetts. In 1770, he served as special prosecutor for the Boston Massacre (his brother, Josiah, assisted John Adams with the defense). A life long loyalist, he evacuated Boston on March 17, 1776 when British fled the cannons from fort Ticonderoga, recently delivered by continental artillery officer, Henry Knox.
speakers.oneLiner: Solicitor General of the Colony of Massachusetts

speakers.name: James Otis
speakers.about: James Otis Jr. was a lawyer in colonial Massachusetts, a member of the Massachusetts provincial assembly, and an early advocate of the Patriot views against British policy that led to the American Revolution.

speakers.name: Mary Katherine Goddard
speakers.about: Mary Katherine Goddard was the postmaster of Baltimore Maryland and the official printer for Continental. She printed the first official printing of the Declaration of Independence.

speakers.name: Benjamin Franklin
speakers.about: Benjamin Franklin (January 17, 1706 to April 17, 1790) was a Founding Father and a polymath, inventor, scientist, printer, politician, freemason and diplomat. Franklin helped to draft the Declaration of Independence and the U.S. Constitution, and he negotiated the 1783 Treaty of Paris ending the Revolutionary War. His scientific pursuits included investigations into electricity, mathematics and mapmaking. A writer known for his wit and wisdom, Franklin also published Poor Richards Almanack, invented bifocal glasses and organized the first successful American lending library.

speakers.name: George Washington
speakers.about: George Washington (1732-99) was commander in chief of the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War (1775-83) and served two terms as the first U.S. president, from 1789 to 1797. The son of a prosperous planter, Washington was raised in colonial Virginia. As a young man, he worked as a surveyor then fought in the French and Indian War (1754-63). During the American Revolution, he led the colonial forces to victory over the British and became a national hero. In 1787, he was elected president of the convention that wrote the U.S. Constitution. Two years later, Washington became Americas first president. Realizing that the way he handled the job would impact how future presidents approached the position, he handed down a legacy of strength, integrity and national purpose. Less than three years after leaving office, he died at his Virginia plantation, Mount Vernon, at age 67.

speakers.name: John Adams
speakers.about: John Adams was born on October 30, 1735, in Quincy, Massachusetts. He was a direct descendant of Puritan colonists from the Massachusetts Bay Colony. He studied at Harvard University, where he received his undergraduate degree and master's, and in 1758 was admitted to the bar. In 1774, he served on the First Continental Congress and helped draft the Declaration of Independence. Adams became the first vice president of the United States and the second president.

speakers.name: Thomas Jefferson
speakers.about: Thomas Jefferson was was a draftsman of the U.S. Declaration of Independence, the nation's first secretary of state, second vice president and third president. As President, he was responsible for the Louisiana Purchase.

speakers.name: Isaiah Thomas
speakers.about: Isaiah Thomas began his work as a full-time printer at age 6. By the time he was 12, he was running his master's print shop almost single handedly.  By age 25 he was the publisher of the most popular newspaper in North America--the Massachusetts Spy.  He as been called the most important patriot printer of the American Revolution.
speakers.oneLiner: Publisher of the radical newspaper, The Massachusetts Spy

speakers.name: Mary Fowle Thomas
speakers.about: Partner of the printer, Isaiah Thomas. Mary stood by her husband through the trials of both poverty and wealth.
speakers.oneLiner: Wife and business partner to Isaiah Thomas, Printer

speakers.name: Abigail Adams
speakers.about: Abigail Adams was the close adviser and confidante of John Adams. She was an ardent supporter of womens rights--particular that right to an education. Abigail managed the family farm in Braintree, Massachusetts alone for extended periods while her husband served in the second continental congress then as ambassador to Great Britain. She chose to have her children inoculated against smallpox at the beginning of the revolutionary war--a practice that was still feared by many American colonists. For more than two centuries, she was the only woman to be the wife of one U.S. resident and the mother of another.

speakers.name: Patrick Ferguson
speakers.about: Ferguson served in the British army from 1759. In 1776 he patented a rifle--one of the earliest practical breechloaders--that was the best military firearm used in the American Revolution. His breechlock was grooved to prevent the actions being jammed with powder. The rifle could be fired six times a minute, a major advance in firepower for the time, but because of official British conservatism not more than 200 of them were used in the war.
speakers.oneLiner: Inventer of the breech loading rifle

speakers.name: Sharon Rogers
speakers.about: Sharon Rogers is a professional storyteller and former reenactor from Colonial Williamsburg. She manages the "Tales in the Garden" exhibit. By day, she is a we developer.

speakers.name: Genelle Pugmire
speakers.about: Genelle is the co-organizer of the Colonial Heritage Festival. In 2005, she organized a celebration of Benjamin Franklin's 300th birthday, and from this event grew the Colonial Days the following year and the Colonial Heritage Festival several years later. By day, Genelle is a reporter for the Daily Herald in Provo.

speakers.name: Daniel Pugmire
speakers.about: Daniel is the co-organizer of the Colonial Heritage Festival. When things running really smoothly, you can find him at the Cup and Quill, doing calligraphy with a feather quill. By day he works for Jet Blue Airlines as a Spanish language reservations specialist.

speakers.name: Jack Pauly
speakers.about: Jack Pauly is a banker from Phoenix

speakers.name: Gove Allen
speakers.about: Gove Allen is a professor of Information systems as Brigham Young University
speakers.oneLiner: President of the Colonial Heritage Foundation

speakers.name: Scott Syme
speakers.about: Scott Syme is a real-life printer

sessions.name: Colonial Games
sessions.description: Native American and Colonial games are available for children and adults to learn and play.
sessions.oneLiner: All work and no play makes George a dull boy

sessions.name: Stories in the Garden
sessions.description: Storytelling was a popular colonial pastime. Some stories were purely for the purpose of amusement while others conveyed important morals. Still others were laced with the gossip of the day. Come sit a spell and experience a yarn in the true colonial tradition.
sessions.oneLiner: Before the days of radio and television, people made their own entertainment

sessions.name: Isaiah Thomas Print Shop
sessions.description: Dubbed the 'Foundry of Sedition' by Boston Loyalists, this print shop was one of the primary sources for information supporting American independence.  As a regular meeting place for the Sons of Liberty, it was frequented by the likes of Samuel Adams, John Hancock, Paul Revere, and James Otis.  You can join them as fugitives from British justice by setting your name in type and printing your own wanted poster.
sessions.oneLiner: Where sedition is invented, manufactured, and distributed

sessions.name: Francis Cooperage
sessions.description: The craftsman who makes buckets, barrels and casks from wood bound together with metal hoops is called a cooper. During the American colonial period, barrels and casks played a major role in transporting goods of many varieties between England and the colonies. They were very durable and easily moved even when very heavily loaded. Oak barrels were vital to the creation and storage of the products of distillers like George Washington and brewers like Samuel Adams. The cooper was a skilled craftsman who worked both with wood and metal to create a watertight, durable container that was the heart of commercial trade both among the colonies and between the colonies and England.
sessions.oneLiner: Buckets, Barells, and casks all made to order

sessions.name: Sarah Davenport Chandlery
sessions.oneLiner: Hand dipped candles and more

sessions.name: Geroge Washington's Camp
sessions.oneLiner: A compete military encampment

sessions.name: Cup and Quill
sessions.oneLiner: Sit a spell and chat a the Calligrapher writes your name on book mark

sessions.name: Abigail's Oven Bakery
sessions.oneLiner: Fresh bread, cookies, and cake all made in the colonial tradition

sessions.name: Silhouette Cutter
sessions.oneLiner: The quick protrait of the 18th century, you can have your own made in just a few mintes

sessions.name: Blacksmith
sessions.description: Perhaps no tradesman was more important to Colonial commerce than was the blacksmith. Although some basic tools were made in England and shipped to the colonies, it was much more common for wrought iron stock to be shipped, where it was made into a variety of tools and hardware by local blacksmiths. During the American colonial period, the blacksmith was often at the forefront of technological innovation. The blacksmith made nails, chain, and gate hardware; he repaired tools for farming and mended wagons; virtually all other craftsmen depended on the local blacksmith directly in one way or another. A young man learned the trade through an apprenticeship that began at around 14 years of age and lasted for seven years. In exchange for being taught the trade as well as how to read, write, and do basic mathematics, the apprentice worked for the master without pay.
sessions.oneLiner: See 18th centruy joinery and woodworking techniques

sessions.name: Continental Artillery & Infantry
sessions.oneLiner: Begin the day as Continental soldiers load and fire cannon typical of the Revolutionary War. Infantry drill and musket firing.

sessions.name: Changing of the Guard
sessions.oneLiner: Watch the changing of the Guard for the 7th as the British troops prepare for the day.

sessions.name: Childrens Militia
sessions.oneLiner: After debating the fate of the tea, young patriots are invited to join the militia to muster as they march through the Colonial Village.

sessions.name: Skirmish
sessions.oneLiner: Witness a skirmish between British troops and a group of Continental militia.

sessions.name: Continental Artillery & Infantry
sessions.oneLiner: Begin the day as Continental soldiers load and fire cannon typical of the Revolutionary War. Infantry drill and musket firing.

sessions.name: Commission of General Washington
sessions.oneLiner: George Washington is commissioned as general and commander-in-chief in the newly formed army of the United Colonies.

sessions.name: Declaration of Independence
sessions.description: With some artistic license, this is the first public reading of the Declaration of Independence in Massachusetts.  News has just reached the state from Pennsylvania and made it way on to the fron page fo the Massachusetts Spy, America's moist popular news outlet.
sessions.oneLiner: Thomas Jefferson, John Adams, General Washington join with like-minded colonials for the first reading of the Declaration in New England- thanks to Isaiah Thomas and his paper, The Massachusetts Spy.

sessions.name: Continental Artillery
sessions.oneLiner: Continental soldiers load and fire cannon typical of the Revolutionary War.

sessions.name: Hog Stealing Trial
sessions.oneLiner: One colonist is accused of stealing anothers hog. Watch as the wheels of British justice turn and help decide the fate of the accused.

sessions.name: Changing of the Guard
sessions.oneLiner: Watch the changing of the Guard for the 7th as the British troops prepare for the day.

sessions.name: Tea Tax Debate
sessions.oneLiner: A spirited debate to decide the fate of the 92,000 pounds of tea in the holds of the Dartmouth, Eleanor, and the Beaver worth over $1,700,000 in todays money- all moored in the Boston Harbor.

sessions.name: Childrens Militia
sessions.oneLiner: After debating the fate of the tea, young patriots are invited to join the militia to muster as they march through the Colonial Village.

sessions.name: Hearing to Indict the Printer
sessions.description: Before Isaiah Thomas can be arrested for calling for the Colonial Assembly to replace Royal Governor Hutchinson with a new governor who answers to the people of Massachusetts, A grand jury must issue an arrest warrant. However, by the 1770's juries (grand or petit) only rarely returned judgments in cases of crimes against the crown. Arrive early an you may be appointed to serve on the Jury.
sessions.oneLiner: Isaiah Thomas is arrested for printing an anti-government article. He is taken to the Old South Church for a grand-jury hearing to determine if a trial will follow.

sessions.name: Continental Artillery & Infantry
sessions.oneLiner: Begin the day as Continental soldiers load and fire cannon typical of the Revolutionary War. Infantry drill and musket firing.

sessions.name: Hog Stealing Trial
sessions.oneLiner: One colonist is accused of stealing anothers hog. Watch as the wheels of British justice turn and help decide the fate of the accused.

sessions.name: Lady Redmaynes Tea
sessions.oneLiner: Come observe Lady Redmayne as she is holding a high tea at the Cup and Quill with some of her closest friends. Politics of the day will surely be discussed. (Sat. & Mon. only)

sessions.name: Skirmish
sessions.oneLiner: Witness a skirmish between British troops and a group of Continental militia.

links.description: Help us improve the festival by giving us feedback and earn a free printed item from the Isaiah Thomas print shop!
Add you name to the Colonial Heritage Foundation email list. We won't share your address with anyone and we'll only send a few messages a year.
You'll enter you comment into a google form and the system someone from the foundation will have your comments texted to them right away!
A colonial reenactment event in Phoenix, Arizona. First weekend in November. Focus is on Military engagement.
See reenactments of the battles of Lexington and Concord at a replica of Mount Vernon in Washington State. First week in August.
America's revolutionary city. Located in Williamsburg, Virginia, it is Americas largest living history museum. Open 365 days a year.

intro.title: Welcome to The Colonial Heritage Festival
intro.text: The Colonial Heritage Festival is the largest American colonial living and reenactment event in the West.

intro.title: Activities for Kids
intro.text: There are lots of hands-on activities for kids, but be sure ask before handling items--some are very, very old.

intro.title: Artisan Exhibits
intro.text: Throughout the festival, you will find exhibits of individulas engaged in crafts from the American colonial period.

intro.title: Presentations
intro.text: Some activities happen only at a partcular time.  Review the schedule to see when and where these presentations happen.  There are some that you won't want miss.
